project.name: Planet Quest
project.tagline: Solar System Educational Adventure for Kids
project.subject: Astronomy / Space Science
features: Fuel bar that fills with correct answers
Fun facts revealed after each planet
educationalGoals: Learn planet order in the solar system
Understand key characteristics of each planet

questions.q: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun. How long does it take Mercury to orbit the Sun?
questions.explain: Mercury zips around the Sun in just 88 Earth days â€” that's its year! It's the fastest planet.

questions.q: Mercury has extreme temperature swings. How hot can its surface get?
questions.explain: Mercury's surface can reach 430Â°C during the day, then plunge to -180Â°C at night. No atmosphere to trap heat!

questions.q: Which spacecraft was the FIRST to visit Mercury?
questions.explain: Mariner 10 flew past Mercury in 1974 and 1975, giving us our first close-up pictures.

questions.q: Mercury is the smallest planet. How does its size compare to Earth?
questions.explain: Mercury is only about 38% of Earth's diameter. You could fit Mercury inside Earth about 18 times!

facts.text: Mercury has the most extreme temperature swings of any planet â€” from 430Â°C in sunlight to -180Â°C in darkness.
A day on Mercury lasts 59 Earth days, but a Mercury year is only 88 Earth days!
Mercury looks a lot like our Moon â€” covered in craters with no atmosphere and no moons of its own.
Despite being closest to the Sun, Venus is actually hotter than Mercury.

questions.q: Venus is the hottest planet. Why is it hotter than Mercury even though it's farther from the Sun?
options: Its thick atmosphere traps heat (greenhouse effect)
questions.explain: Venus has a thick atmosphere of COâ‚‚ that traps heat like a blanket â€” a runaway greenhouse effect!

questions.q: Venus spins in the opposite direction to most planets. What does this mean?
options: The Sun rises in the west on Venus
questions.explain: Venus rotates 'retrograde' â€” backwards! So the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east there.

questions.q: How long is a DAY on Venus compared to a year on Venus?
options: A day is shorter than a year
A day is longer than a year
questions.explain: A Venus day (243 Earth days) is actually longer than its year (225 Earth days). Wild!

questions.q: Venus is often called Earth's 'twin.' Why?
questions.explain: Venus and Earth are nearly the same size and mass â€” but Venus is an extreme world with crushing pressure.

facts.text: Venus is the hottest planet at 465Â°C â€” hot enough to melt lead!
Winds at the top of Venus's clouds reach 360 km/h and circle the whole planet in just 4 days.
Venus is covered in thick yellow clouds made of sulfuric acid.
Venus is the brightest object in our sky after the Sun and Moon â€” it's often called the 'Morning Star.'

questions.q: What percentage of Earth's surface is covered by water?
questions.explain: About 71% of Earth's surface is water! That's why Earth looks blue from space â€” the 'Blue Marble.'

questions.q: What protects Earth from harmful solar radiation?
questions.explain: The ozone layer in our atmosphere filters out dangerous ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the Sun.

questions.q: How old is planet Earth?
questions.explain: Earth formed about 4.5 billion years ago from a cloud of gas and dust around our young Sun.

questions.q: Earth is the only known planet with plate tectonics. What does that mean?
options: Earth's crust is broken into moving pieces
questions.explain: Earth's crust is broken into giant 'tectonic plates' that slowly drift â€” creating mountains, earthquakes, and volcanoes!

facts.text: Earth has a powerful magnetic field created by its molten iron core â€” it deflects harmful solar wind.
Earth's Moon is unusually large compared to our planet. It stabilizes Earth's tilt, giving us stable seasons.
Earth is the only planet in our solar system known to host life. So far!
Around 100 lightning bolts strike Earth's surface every single second.

questions.q: Why is Mars called the 'Red Planet'?
questions.explain: Mars is red because its surface is covered in iron oxide â€” basically rust! The whole planet is rusty.

questions.q: Mars has the tallest volcano in the solar system. What is it called?
questions.explain: Olympus Mons is about 22 km tall â€” nearly 3 times the height of Mount Everest!

questions.q: How many moons does Mars have?
questions.explain: Mars has two small moons â€” Phobos and Deimos. They look more like captured asteroids than proper moons.

questions.q: The Perseverance rover landed on Mars in 2021. What is it looking for?
questions.explain: Perseverance is searching for signs of ancient life in Jezero Crater, which may have been a lake billions of years ago.

facts.text: Mars has massive dust storms that can engulf the entire planet for months at a time.
Mars has polar ice caps made of frozen COâ‚‚ (dry ice) and water ice.
More than 50 missions have been sent to Mars â€” more than any other planet!
A Martian day (sol) is 24 hours and 37 minutes â€” very close to an Earth day.

questions.q: Jupiter is the largest planet. How many Earths could fit inside Jupiter?
questions.explain: About 1,300 Earths could fit inside Jupiter! It's SO massive it has more mass than all other planets combined.

questions.q: Jupiter's Great Red Spot is famous. What is it?
questions.explain: The Great Red Spot is a storm that has been raging for at least 350 years â€” bigger than Earth itself!

questions.q: How many moons does Jupiter have?
questions.explain: Jupiter has over 95 known moons! Its four largest â€” Io, Europa, Ganymede, Callisto â€” are called the Galilean moons.

questions.q: Jupiter acts like a 'cosmic vacuum cleaner.' Why is that important for Earth?
options: Its gravity pulls in asteroids that might hit Earth
questions.explain: Jupiter's massive gravity captures many comets and asteroids â€” shielding the inner planets including Earth.

facts.text: Wind speeds on Jupiter reach up to 620 km/h â€” much faster than any hurricane on Earth.
Europa, one of Jupiter's moons, has a liquid ocean under its icy crust and might harbor life!
Jupiter emits more heat than it receives from the Sun â€” it has its own internal heat source.
Jupiter has powerful auroras at its poles, thousands of times stronger than Earth's northern lights.

questions.q: Saturn's rings are famous. What are they made of?
questions.explain: Saturn's rings are made of billions of chunks of ice and rock, ranging from tiny grains to house-sized boulders.

questions.q: Saturn is the least dense planet. What does this mean?
questions.explain: Saturn is so light (mostly hydrogen and helium gas) that it would float if you could find an ocean big enough!

questions.q: How many moons does Saturn have?
questions.explain: Saturn has over 146 known moons â€” the most of any planet. Titan, its largest, even has rivers and lakes of liquid methane!

questions.q: Saturn has a hexagonal storm at its north pole. How big is it?
questions.explain: The hexagonal jet stream at Saturn's north pole is about twice the size of Earth â€” and it's been there for decades!

facts.text: Saturn's rings stretch 280,000 km wide but are only about 10â€“100 meters thick.
Titan has rivers, lakes, and rain â€” but made of liquid methane, not water!
A Saturn year lasts 29.4 Earth years. If you were born on Saturn, you'd barely be 2 years old at age 60!
The Cassini spacecraft orbited Saturn for 13 years, revealing stunning details about the rings and moons.

questions.q: Uranus is the 'tilted planet.' By how many degrees is it tilted?
questions.explain: Uranus is tilted 98 degrees â€” it essentially rotates on its side! Its poles get 42 years of sunlight, then 42 years of darkness.

questions.q: What gives Uranus its blue-green color?
options: Methane in its atmosphere absorbs red light
questions.explain: Methane gas in Uranus's atmosphere absorbs red light and reflects blue-green light, giving it that unique color.

questions.q: Uranus is an ice giant. What is its interior likely made of?
options: A hot ocean of water, ammonia, and methane
questions.explain: Uranus likely has a slushy interior of water, ammonia, and methane â€” extremely hot but under huge pressure.

questions.q: How many moons does Uranus have, and what are they named after?
questions.explain: Uranus has 27 known moons all named after characters from Shakespeare and Alexander Pope â€” Titania, Oberon, Miranda and more!

facts.text: Uranus is the coldest planetary atmosphere in the solar system at -224Â°C â€” colder than Neptune!
All of Uranus's moons are named after characters from Shakespeare and Alexander Pope's poetry.
Uranus has 13 known rings â€” much darker and narrower than Saturn's bright icy rings.
Because of its extreme tilt, one pole of Uranus points almost directly at the Sun during parts of its orbit.

questions.q: Neptune was predicted by mathematics before it was even seen. Who predicted it?
questions.explain: In 1846, mathematicians Urbain Le Verrier and John Adams predicted Neptune's location from Uranus's wobble â€” and it was found exactly there!

questions.q: What are the strongest winds in the solar system found on Neptune?
questions.explain: Neptune has the fastest winds in the solar system â€” reaching up to 2,100 km/h! 6 times faster than Earth's strongest hurricanes.

questions.q: Neptune's largest moon, Triton, does something unusual. What?
options: It has a city on it
It has rings of its own
questions.explain: Triton orbits Neptune backwards (retrograde) â€” the only large moon in the solar system to do this. It was likely captured.

questions.q: How long does it take Neptune to orbit the Sun once?
questions.explain: Neptune takes 165 Earth years to orbit the Sun. It has only completed one full orbit since its discovery in 1846!

facts.text: Neptune is the only planet in the solar system not visible to the naked eye from Earth.
It's called Neptune after the Roman god of the sea â€” fitting for a deep blue ice giant.
Scientists think it might rain diamonds deep inside Neptune due to extreme pressure and carbon-rich atmosphere.
Only one spacecraft has ever visited Neptune â€” Voyager 2 flew past in 1989 and is still our best source of close-up data.
